displaytitle: A travers les Ateliers - Fichtre! . . . Epatant! . . . Sapristi! . . . Superbe! . . . ca parle! . . . (Through the studios - The Deuce! . . . Amazing! . . . Good God! . . . Superb! . . . it speaks! . . . )
inscribed:
Printed above stone, upper left and right: Souvenirs d’Artistes. / 285

Printed title above stone, center: A TRAVERS LES ATELIERS

Artist initials in stone, lower left: HD

Printed below stone, center: Imp. Bertauts, Paris.

Printed caption in lower margin, center: Fichtre !... Epatant !... Sapristi !... Superbe!... ç parle!...

titles.title: A travers les Ateliers - Fichtre! . . . Epatant! . . . Sapristi! . . . Superbe! . . . ca parle! . . . (Through the studios - The Deuce! . . . Amazing! . . . Good God! . . . Superb! . . . it speaks! . . . )

makers.displaydate: 1808–1879; born Valmondois, France; died Marseille, France
makers.displaymaker: Honoré Daumier, 1808–1879; born Valmondois, France; died Marseille, France

texts.textentryhtml:
Until 1860, the celebrated caricaturist Daumier regularly supplied scathing anti-monarchist lithographs to several populist newspapers. He then devoted himself to painting, while occasionally contributing lithographs and wood engravings to more recently established journals, including Le Boulevard, issued in 1862 and 1863. Daumier provided eleven lithographs to this publication, including these two humorous observations of the fashionable but rapidly changing Parisian art world.

In the studio scene, artists crowd around a colleague’s painting, which is not visible to us. It is thought that the broadly smiling man closest to the canvas could be Daumier himself. The outdoor setting pokes fun at the Impressionists’ determined efforts to paint outdoors in order to record changing light effects in nature.
